title: Tens of Thousands Still in Dark in Tennessee After Winter Storm
summary: Outages are concentrated in Memphis area, as eastern U.S. recovers from snow and ice. Tens of thousands of people were still without power Sunday, mostly in the hard-hit Memphis, Tenn., area, days after a snow and ice storm hit a swath of the southern and eastern U.S.

title: A U.S. Ambassador Takes Mexico's Side
summary: Ken Salazar contradicts Team Biden on AMLO's energy reform.. "Muy bien, Ken," Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador crowed at a Friday press conference in Mexico City. He was congratulating U.S. Ambassador Ken Salazar for contradicting the Biden administration as the American diplomat finished a visit to Mexico's Chamber of Deputies the day before.

title: Mike Pence's Constitution
summary: The former Vice President stands up to Trump, despite the potential political cost.. The United States desperately needs a Republican Party that is a sane alternative to the ruling Democrats who have lurched to the coercive left. On that score, Americans should welcome Mike Pence's stand Friday for constitutional principle on elections no matter its political cost.

title: U.S. Readies New Asia-Pacific Economic Strategy to Counter China
summary: Biden administration aims to work more closely with Asian nations on trade issues, but some say effort won't substitute for previous pact the U.S. abandoned. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration is preparing to unveil its first broad economic strategy for the Asia-Pacific region, a move awaited by U.S. allies and American business groups that are uneasy about China's expanding influence in the region.

title: New York's Gerrymander Is an Affront to Democratic Principles
summary: I want my party to win as many House seats as possible. But not this way.. Live from New York, it's gerrymandering. Last week Gov. Kathy Hochul signed into law a new congressional map that is expected to eliminate half of the state's Republican delegation. The map favors Democrats in 85% of House seats in a state Joe Biden won with 60% of the popular vote.

title: White House Warns Russian Invasion of Ukraine Could Come 'Any Day Now'
summary: Thousands of civilians could be killed or wounded if Russia mounts all-out attack, U.S. intelligence assessments say. White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan warned Sunday that a Russian invasion of Ukraine could be imminent and might entail a high cost for the civilians living there.

title: Europe's Next Refugee Crisis
summary: The EU isn't ready for millions of Ukrainians if Russia invades.. A Russian invasion of Ukraine would have devastating humanitarian consequences, and one of them might be another refugee crisis in Europe. Let's hope the Continent does better this time.

title: Single-Payer Dies Again in California
summary: The cost is too much even for America's progressive paradise.. California is the land where progressive dreams are born, die and reincarnated. Democrats in Sacramento last month revived single-payer healthcare legislation, only to watch it expire again last week. Misguided hope springs eternal.

title: Rushing to a Weaker Iran Deal
summary: The U.S. makes another pre-emptive concession, as Tehran demands more.. The diplomatic signs point to the Biden Administration striking a revised nuclear deal with Iran, and the latest bad news is sanctions relief even before an accord is struck.

title: Wealth Is Knowledge
summary: Economist George Gilder explains how capitalism is the most charitable system.. The stock-market carnage came fast and furious, wrecking GameStop -like memes and get-rich-quick crypto schemes and cracking SPACs. The ringleader, Robinhood, fueled by stimulus checks, is a good proxy for the excess. Its stock is down almost 80% from its August peak. It is a fine time to ask: What is wealth? Is it Justin Bieber dropping $1.3 million on a Bored Ape Yacht Club nonfungible token? Ha! More important, how do you keep wealth?

title: 'The Color of Abolition' Review: Allies Against Slavery
summary: A group biography of William Lloyd Garrison, Frederick Douglass and their associates is also a history of the abolitionist movement, 1831-65.. On New Year's Day 1831, a youthful New England newspaperman with a political bent launched his latest venture in social reform, promising a new era in American abolitionism. In the first issue of the Liberator, William Lloyd Garrison, who had just turned 25, famously proclaimed: "I will be as harsh as truth, and as uncompromising as justice . . . AND I WILL BE HEARD." And, indeed, 1831 did mark a watershed in the American antislavery movement. Supported by Boston's free black community and emanating from a small office on Boston's Cornhill Street, Garrison's strident antislavery message galvanized American abolitionism and spearheaded a campaign of speakers, pamphlets and fundraising that generated auxiliaries of his recently formed New England Anti-Slavery Society throughout the North.

title: Putin Targets Germany, NATO's Weakest Link
summary: Biden should encourage Berlin to come off the sidelines and stop giving Moscow a pass.. As the world wonders if Vladimir Putin will invade Ukraine, the battle for the West is already under way. Without firing a shot, Mr. Putin has attacked the trans-Atlantic alliance at its weakest link: Germany. When Chancellor Olaf Scholz visits the White House on Monday, it will be the most important meeting between a U.S. president and a German leader since before the Iraq war.

title: The Fed Should Raise Interest Rates, but Gently
summary: Tightening is obviously necessary, but getting it right calls for caution, flexibility and humility.. The Federal Reserve may be in for a series of tough calls in 2022 and, naturally, all financial-market eyes will be watching. What will the Federal Open Market Committee do? What should it do?

summary: 'I wore my mask the entire game and when people ask for a photograph I hold my breath.'. Joseph Gedeon reporting for Politico, Feb. 3:

title: A Uyghur Skier Became Face of Winter Olympics. The Next Day, She Vanished From the Spotlight.
summary: Chinese athlete and Olympic torch carrier Dinigeer Yilamujiang finished 43rd in her Olympic debut. ZHANGJIAKOU, China-She was the face of Friday's Olympic opening ceremony: a young Uyghur athlete from Xinjiang, the center of human-rights allegations dividing China and the West, carrying the Olympic flame for the host nation.

title: Economy Week Ahead: Trade, Inflation, Layoffs
summary: U.S. inflation is expected to hit a multidecade high in January. U.S. inflation data highlight this week's slate of economic releases.

title: Andrew Cuomo Plans Comeback Months After Sexual-Harassment Claims
summary: Former New York governor is considering how to make his first public appearance since leaving office. Former New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo and his aides are intensifying an effort to revive his public standing, including discussing how to make his first public appearance since resigning in August, according to people close to him.

title: Positive Covid Test in Hong Kong Starts Business Traveler on Monthlong Quarantine
summary: Two days of fever, 28 days in hospital; city's Covid-19 containment measures are among the strictest in the world. HONG KONG-When Yudi Soetjiptadi made it back home to Hong Kong in December after a business trip to Africa, he knew he would have to spend a week in a city quarantine center and then 14 more days of isolation in a hotel. Then he tested positive for Covid-19. It was the start of a monthlong odyssey.

title: Stock Funds Slumped to Start 2022
summary: The average fund dropped 6.7% in January. Also: The Super Bowl Predictor of the market says to root for the Rams.. It hasn't been a happy new year so far for fund investors.

title: Why Colleges Don't Care About Free Speech
summary: It's incentives more than ideology, and there's a simple fix.. Georgetown University's law school violated its own speech policy last week when it placed Ilya Shapiro, a newly hired administrator, on leave over a tweet that offended some students. Why do universities make grandiloquent commitments to freedom of speech, then fail to honor them? It isn't so much an issue of ideology as a problem of incentives.

title: BlackRock's Climate-Crusade Doubletalk
summary: CEO Larry Fink says companies should have a 'purpose,' but pushes them to advance what he favors.. 'Stakeholder capitalism is not about politics. . . . It is capitalism." Or so BlackRock CEO Larry Fink claimed in his annual letter to America's CEOs last month, in which he called on corporate chiefs to stay true to their own companies' "purpose."

title: Amnesty International Gets Israel Dead Wrong
summary: Maintaining a Jewish majority is the way to prevent 'apartheid.'. Thank you for standing up for Israel in your editorial "The 'Apartheid' Libel of Israel" (Feb. 1). Israel was established as the nation-state of the Jewish people in 1948 with broad international support based in part on the lessons learned from the Holocaust. While founded as the Jewish national home, Israel was established first and foremost as a democracy. In fact, the composition of today's Israeli government is a strong testament to its democracy. Its ministers include Jews and Arabs, the secular and religious, immigrants, persons with disabilities and members of the LGBTQ community. That is not "apartheid." Today's government, and the Knesset, reflect all the diversity and inclusiveness that epitomizes Israel.

title: What the Unemployed Are Doing With Their Time
summary: Vastly different experiences out of the labor force.. Nicholas Eberstadt's take on unemployment ("The Underside of the 'Great Resignation'" by Mene Ukueberuwa, Weekend Interview, Jan. 22) was an oversimplification of our pandemic-era reality. Sure, there will always be unemployed people loafing around and watching screens all day. But for families such as ours, having only one parent working full time during the pandemic has been a blessing. It has allowed one parent to focus on a job, while the other can deal with the multiple pivots to virtual schooling for our kids.

title: Politicizing Florida's Response to Climate Change
summary: Does Gov. Ron DeSantis think his audience is gullible?. Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis must either think his audience is very gullible or he doesn't recognize what he is saying when he says, "We're not doing any left-wing stuff" ("Republicans Adjust Climate Message," U.S. News, Jan. 24).

title: The Three Rs Are Treated Differently
summary: People are perfectly willing to announce that they aren't good at math.. Regarding David Shaywitz's review of "Making Numbers Count" (Bookshelf, Jan. 31): My wife is a retired math teacher. She has always found it amusing that people are perfectly willing to announce that they aren't good at math but would be embarrassed to admit the same about reading.

title: Investors Flock to 'I Savings Bonds' for Protection Against Inflation
summary: They have all sorts of advantages for those worried about rising prices. One caveat: There is no secondary market.. As inflation rises, another low-risk investment is getting more attention: the tried-and-true Series I savings bond known as inflation or I bonds.

title: Worker Absences Hold Back Companies' Growth
summary: The Omicron variant has hit staffing hard, and lingering pressures remain for some employers. Employers from McDonald's Corp. to home builder PulteGroup Inc. said staffing pressures caused by hiring challenges and surging Covid-19 cases suppressed growth or cut into operations in the fourth quarter.

title: Climate Scientists Encounter Limits of Computer Models, Bedeviling Policy
summary: Resume Subscription. BOULDER, Colo.-For almost five years, an international consortium of scientists was chasing clouds, determined to solve a problem that bedeviled climate-change forecasts for a generation: How do these wisps of water vapor affect global warming?

summary: Crypto companies strive to be household names, spending millions of dollars on sports broadcast sponsorships. Who will dominate Super Bowl LVI? Madison Avenue's money is on crypto.

title: Lawmakers Signal Stopgap Spending Bill Needed as Talks Continue
summary: Military and nonmilitary increases debated; government funding is set to run out on Feb. 18. WASHINGTON-Negotiators remained locked in talks about overall spending levels for the current fiscal year and special items such as Covid-19 funding, with lawmakers set to turn this week to a short-term bill to keep the government running if no deal is reached.

title: What We Don't Know About the Stock Market
summary: Meta's down, Amazon's up, and there are four big questions for investors. Extraordinary moves in Big Tech stocks in response to small changes in their earnings show what a wacky market we're in. Uncertainty about the future of the economy in general and the tech sector in particular are extremely high. In short, nobody knows anything.

summary: Cincinnati built its team through getting the No. 1 pick and getting Joe Burrow. Los Angeles trades away its top selections. They reached the championship by following opposite blueprints.. title: China's Slowdown to Limit Global Growth but Not Undermine World Economy
summary: Lukewarm demand from China poses risks to commodity producers, though it could ease inflationary pressure. HONG KONG-A prolonged slowdown in China's economic growth could hurt some multinational companies and commodity producers for years to come, casting a shadow over the global recovery from the pandemic-but likely not derailing it entirely.

title: Queen Elizabeth Says She Wants Prince Charles's Wife to Be Queen Camilla
summary: Commemorating 70th anniversary of her accession to the throne, Queen Elizabeth resolves question hanging over her succession. LONDON-Queen Elizabeth II has resolved a question hanging over her succession, stating that Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, should be referred to as queen once Prince Charles accedes the throne.

title: Airlines Face Unexpected Safety Issue in Pandemic: More Bird Strikes
summary: With drop-off in global travel, birds moved into quiet airports. Now, planes are flying again, creating collision hazard. Airlines are contending with an unexpected consequence of the pandemic: a rising rate in bird collisions.

title: Moroccan Boy Trapped in Well for Four Days Dies
summary: Rescuers reached five-year-old Rayan Aourram after tunneling into the well in an effort that captured world-wide attention. A young boy trapped for four days in a well in northern Morocco has died, according to the country's royal palace, after a frantic rescue effort that captured world-wide attention.

title: A Big Tech Trade Is Losing Its Luster
summary: The NYSE FANG+ Index, which tracks popular stocks like Meta Platforms, Apple, Amazon and Netflix, has tumbled 10% this year. The stock market's popular FAANG trade is starting to show cracks.

summary: Inflation-wary investors are flocking to TIPS rather than to conventional bonds. But they might not understand the drawbacks as well as they should.. summary: Most Popular News. Teachers have quit in droves during the pandemic. Sometimes bumpy, their paths provide a lesson plan for others looking to leap from the classroom to the corporate world.

title: Judges Weigh More Biden Vaccine-Mandate Cases After Supreme Court Rulings
summary: Several lower courts considering challenges to the administration's other Covid-19 vaccine requirements. Courts around the country are weighing how to apply the U.S. Supreme Court's recent mixed guidance on the federal government's power to impose Covid-19 vaccine mandates, as judges consider whether the Biden administration can enforce such requirements on groups including government contractors and federal workers.

title: Singer Lata Mangeshkar, 'Nightingale of India,' Dies at 92
summary: Ms. Mangeshkar's distinctive vocals were dubbed over lip-syncing actors in lavishly choreographed Bollywood musicals. NEW DELHI-Lata Mangeshkar, an Indian singer and cultural icon who enchanted generations of Bollywood audiences, died on Sunday at Breach Candy Hospital in Mumbai. She was 92 years old.

title: Team USA Wins Its First Medal of Beijing Olympics-a Snowboarding Silver
summary: Julia Marino finished second in snowboard slopestyle. It was the first time the U.S. hasn't won a gold medal in the event.. When all else is in doubt, Americans will win a medal in snowboard slopestyle. But for the first time in the event's Olympic history, it wasn't gold.

title: Beijing Winter Olympics Opening Day Viewership 43% Lower Than in 2018
summary: Preliminary figures from NBC reflect declining audience for the Games over recent Olympic cycles. The opening day of the Winter Olympics in Beijing drew nearly 16 million viewers in the U.S. on Friday across NBC's TV and streaming platforms, a roughly 43% drop from the kickoff for the Games in Pyeongchang in 2018, according to preliminary figures from the network.

title: Joe Rogan Apologizes for Using Racial Slur During Past Podcasts
summary: Spotify podcaster takes to Instagram after video compilation surfaces. Joe Rogan apologized on Saturday after a video emerged of the star podcaster using a racial slur in previous episodes.
